docs.title: GitHub Copilot Prompting Workshop
docs.text: Master GitHub Copilot through hands-on prompting exercises. Build a Python calculator that evolves from 15 lines to 350+ lines using ONLY AI prompts—no manual coding required!

docs.title: 🎯 Workshop Overview
docs.text: Duration: 4 hours Focus: Prompting skills (not coding skills) Target Audience: Developers with mixed backgrounds Validation: Automated test suites

docs.title: What You’ll Learn
docs.text:
• ✅ All GitHub Copilot modes (Inline, Chat Ask/Plan/Agent, Beast Mode)
  • ✅ When to use each mode for maximum effectiveness
  • ✅ Craft effective prompts for different scenarios
  • ✅ Configure custom instructions and agents (.github directory)
  • ✅ Test-driven AI development
  • ✅ Cross-language development (Python → JavaScript)

docs.title: What You’ll Build
docs.text:
Transform a minimal 15-line calculator into a sophisticated 350+ line application:

Starting Point → Final Result - Basic add/subtract → Full scientific calculator - No structure → OOP with Calculator class - No tests → 90%+ test coverage - No docs → Comprehensive documentation - Python only → Python + JavaScript versions - No UI → CLI, GUI, REST API options

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Required: - Python 3.12 or higher - VS Code with GitHub Copilot extension - GitHub Copilot subscription (or trial) - Basic terminal/command line familiarity

Optional: - Node.js 16+ (for Exercise 15: JavaScript conversion)

docs.title: GitHub Copilot Prompting Workshop - Exercises
docs.text: This workshop teaches GitHub Copilot prompting mastery through 15 progressive exercises. You’ll evolve a simple Python calculator from ~15 lines to 350+ lines using ONLY prompting—no manual coding!

docs.title: Workshop Structure
docs.text: Duration: 4 hours Validation: Run pytest tests/test_exN.py after each exercise Core Principle: ALL code additions done via Copilot prompting

docs.title: Exercise 1: Hello Copilot - Inline Suggestions (10 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Inline suggestions only Starting Point: Current calculator.py with add/subtract

Your Task: Use ONLY inline suggestions to add: - multiply(x, y) function - divide(x, y) function with division by zero handling

Prompting Strategy: 

# Write function signature and let Copilot complete:
def multiply(x: float, y: float) -> float:
    # Copilot will suggest implementation

# Or write a comment first:
# Function to divide two numbers with error handling
def divide(x: float, y: float) -> float:

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex1.py passes Learning Goal: Master inline suggestion flow (Tab to accept, modify as needed)

docs.title: Exercise 2: Chat Ask - Quick Enhancements (10 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: GitHub Copilot Chat (Ask mode) Starting Point: Your Ex1 code with 4 operations

Your Task: Use Chat to ASK Copilot for help: - Add modulo(x, y) operation - Add power(x, y) operation (exponentiation)

Example Prompts: 

"Add a modulo function that returns the remainder of division"

"Add a power function for exponentiation (x to the power of y)"

"How do I handle modulo by zero?"

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex2.py passes Learning Goal: When to use Chat Ask vs continuing with inline

docs.title: Exercise 3: Chat Iteration - Refinement (10 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Ask (iterative refinement) Starting Point: Your Ex2 code with 6 operations

Your Task: Use Chat to improve code quality: - Add input validation (handle non-numeric inputs) - Improve error messages to be user-friendly - Make all functions handle both int and float inputs

Example Prompts: 

"Add validation to ensure all inputs are numeric"

"Improve my error messages to be more helpful to users"

"Make sure all functions can handle both integers and floats"

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex3.py passes Learning Goal: Iterative prompting to refine Copilot’s output

docs.title: Exercise 4: Chat Plan - Scientific Functions (15 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Plan mode Starting Point: Your Ex3 code

Your Task: Use PLAN mode to design scientific calculator: 1. First, PLAN the architecture 2. Then implement based on plan

Example Prompts: 

"Plan how to add scientific functions (sqrt, log, sin, cos, tan) to my calculator. 
Should they be in a separate module or integrated? Consider maintainability."

"What's the best way to structure scientific calculator functions?"

[After reviewing plan]
"Implement the scientific functions using approach #2 from your plan"

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex4.py passes Learning Goal: Difference between Chat Ask (quick) vs Plan (complex)

docs.title: Exercise 5: Documentation with Plan (12 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Plan → Agent execution Starting Point: Your Ex4 code with scientific functions

Your Task: 1. PLAN a documentation strategy 2. Have Agent implement comprehensive documentation

Example Prompts: 

"Plan a documentation strategy for my calculator project. What should be documented 
and how? Consider docstrings, README, and usage examples."

[After plan]
"Implement the documentation plan. Add Google-style docstrings to all functions 
and create a comprehensive README.md with usage examples."

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex5.py passes Learning Goal: Using Plan for non-code artifacts

docs.title: Exercise 6: Test-Driven Addition (12 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Ask + Plan combination Starting Point: Your Ex5 documented code

Your Task: Generate comprehensive test suite 1. PLAN test structure 2. Generate pytest tests

Example Prompts: 

"Plan a testing strategy for my calculator. What test scenarios should I cover?"

"Generate a pytest test file (test_calculator.py) that tests all my calculator 
functions with normal cases, edge cases, and error scenarios. Use parametrized 
tests where appropriate."

"Add test cases for division by zero and other error conditions"

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex6.py passes Learning Goal: When to switch between Ask and Plan modes

docs.title: Exercise 7: Agent Mode - Class Refactoring (15 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Agent (autonomous multi-step) Starting Point: Your Ex6 tested code

Your Task: Let Agent refactor to OOP structure

Example Prompt: 

"Refactor my calculator into object-oriented structure. Create a Calculator class 
with all operations as methods. Maintain all existing functionality and add a 
calculation history feature that tracks all operations performed."

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex7.py passes Learning Goal: Agent autonomy for complex refactoring

docs.title: Exercise 8: Agent Mode - Memory System (15 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Agent Starting Point: Your Ex7 Calculator class with history

Your Task: Enhance history system

Example Prompt: 

"Add comprehensive history management to my Calculator class:
- History storage in memory (list of calculations)
- Method to show last N calculations
- Method to clear history
- Method to export history to a text file
- Ability to recall the last result for use in new calculations"

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex8.py passes Learning Goal: Agent handling multiple related features

docs.title: Exercise 9: Agent Mode - Advanced CLI (15 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Agent Starting Point: Your Ex8 Calculator with history

Your Task: Implement sophisticated command-line interface

Example Prompt: 

"Implement an advanced CLI for my calculator using argparse:
- Interactive mode: continuous calculations with menu
- Single-calculation mode: one operation then exit
- Command-line arguments for quick calculations
- Support for loading/saving calculator preferences to config.json
- Help text showing all available commands"

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex9.py passes Learning Goal: Agent managing complex architectural changes

docs.title: Exercise 10: Custom Instructions Setup (20 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Custom Instructions (.github/copilot-instructions.md) Starting Point: Your Ex9 full-featured calculator

Your Task: 1. Create .github/copilot-instructions.md with project standards 2. Use Agent to add a feature WITH instructions active

Example Prompts: 

"Help me create a .github/copilot-instructions.md file for my calculator project.
Include:
- Code style requirements (Python 3.12 type hints, Google docstrings)
- Testing standards (pytest, 90% coverage goal)
- Architecture principles (class-based, modular design)
- Documentation standards with examples"

[After creating instructions file]
"Following the instructions in .github/copilot-instructions.md, add a plugin 
system that allows extending the calculator with custom operations."

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex10.py passes Learning Goal: Setting persistent project context for all Copilot interactions

docs.title: Exercise 11: Instructions-Driven Enhancement (15 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Custom Instructions + Agent Starting Point: Your Ex10 code with instructions file

Your Task: Update instructions and refactor ENTIRE codebase

Example Prompts: 

"Update .github/copilot-instructions.md to require:
- Type hints on ALL functions (parameters and returns)
- Example usage in every docstring
- Consistent error handling patterns
- Follow Google Python Style Guide strictly"

[After updating instructions]
"Review and refactor my ENTIRE calculator codebase to match the updated standards
in .github/copilot-instructions.md. Ensure every function has proper type hints,
comprehensive docstrings with examples, and consistent style."

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex11.py passes Learning Goal: Using instructions for consistency and quality

docs.title: Exercise 12: Custom Agent - Testing Specialist (20 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Custom Agent (.github/copilot-agents/test-agent.yml) Starting Point: Your Ex11 refined codebase

Your Task: 1. Create custom testing agent 2. Use it to enhance test coverage

Example Prompts: 

"Create a custom Copilot agent YAML file for a testing specialist:
- Expert in pytest and Python testing
- Focuses on edge cases and error scenarios
- Aims for 95%+ coverage
- Suggests parametrized tests
Save to .github/copilot-agents/test-agent.yml"

[After creating agent]
"@test-agent Analyze my calculator.py and generate comprehensive tests to reach 
95% coverage. Focus on edge cases I might have missed, error scenarios, and 
boundary conditions. Add parametrized tests for similar test cases."

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex12.py passes Learning Goal: Creating task-specific AI assistants

docs.title: Exercise 13: Custom Agent - Performance Optimizer (20 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Custom Agent (.github/copilot-agents/perf-agent.yml) Starting Point: Your Ex12 well-tested calculator

Your Task: 1. Create performance optimization agent 2. Optimize calculator performance

Example Prompts: 

"Create a custom Copilot agent for performance optimization:
- Analyzes algorithmic complexity
- Suggests caching and memoization
- Provides benchmark code
- Considers memory vs speed tradeoffs
Save to .github/copilot-agents/perf-agent.yml"

[After creating agent]
"@perf-agent Analyze my Calculator class for performance bottlenecks. Suggest 
optimizations for:
- Repeated calculations (caching)
- History operations (efficient data structures)
- Large number handling
Provide benchmark code to measure improvements."

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex13.py passes Learning Goal: Specialized agents for specific domains

docs.title: Exercise 14: Beast Mode - Parallel Development (30 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: ALL modes simultaneously (Beast Mode) Starting Point: Your Ex13 optimized calculator

Your Task: Add 4 major features simultaneously using all Copilot capabilities

Example Prompt: 

"I want to add four major features to my calculator simultaneously:

1. GUI Interface: Create a tkinter-based graphical interface
2. Database Persistence: Store calculation history in SQLite database
3. REST API: Create a Flask API for remote calculations
4. Unit Conversion: Add length, weight, and temperature conversions

Plan the architecture to ensure these features integrate well, then implement
all four with appropriate tests and documentation. Use the fastest approach
for each component."

Strategy: - Accept inline suggestions for quick wins - Let Agent handle complex features (GUI, API) - Use @test-agent for testing new features - Use Chat Plan to coordinate integration

Success Criteria: pytest tests/test_ex14.py passes Learning Goal: Managing multiple AI suggestions and features simultaneously

docs.title: Exercise 15: Language Conversion - JavaScript (30 min)
docs.text:
Copilot Mode: Chat Agent (cross-language translation) Starting Point: Your complete Python calculator

Your Task: Convert entire application to JavaScript/Node.js

Example Prompt: 

"Convert my complete Python calculator application to JavaScript (Node.js):

Requirements:
- Maintain ALL features from the Python version
- Use ES6+ syntax with classes
- Convert pytest tests to Jest format
- Create package.json with proper dependencies
- Follow JavaScript best practices and idioms
- Ensure equivalent functionality and test coverage
- Add README section explaining how to run the JavaScript version

Provide a complete, working JavaScript implementation with passing tests."

Follow-Up Prompts (if needed): 

"Fix the Jest tests that are failing in the history feature"

"Add TypeScript type definitions for better type safety"

"Compare performance between Python and JavaScript versions"

Success Criteria: npm test (or jest) passes for JavaScript version Learning Goal: Agent capabilities across programming languages

docs.title: After Each Exercise:
docs.text:

  2. Check for passing tests:

  3. All tests should pass (green)
  4. If tests fail, read the error message

  5. Use Copilot Chat: “Why is test_X failing?”

  6. Iterate if needed:

  7. Refine your prompts based on test failures

  9. Re-run tests until all pass

  10. Move to next exercise once tests pass

docs.title: Troubleshooting Tips:
docs.text:
If inline suggestions aren’t working well: - Make your comments more specific - Write function signatures first - Try Chat Ask mode instead

If Chat responses are too vague: - Add more context about your code - Be more specific about requirements - Switch to Plan mode for complex tasks

If Agent goes in wrong direction: - Interrupt and redirect: “Stop, try a different approach” - Provide more constraints upfront - Break task into smaller steps

If tests are failing: - Use Chat: “Why is [test_name] failing?” - Check test file to understand requirements - Iterate your prompts until tests pass

Learning Objective: Get comfortable with inline suggestion flow

Teaching Points: - Copilot watches as you type - Tab accepts, Esc dismisses - Alt+[ and Alt+] cycle through suggestions - Comment-driven: write comment, then signature - Type hints help generate better suggestions

Live Demo (5 min before students start): 

# Show typing this slowly:
def multiply(x: float, y: float) -> float:
    # Pause here - Copilot suggests return x * y
    # Press Tab to accept

Common Issues: - Copilot not suggesting: Check if enabled, try restarting VS Code - Wrong suggestions: Be more specific in function name/comment - Students accepting blindly: Remind them to READ before accepting

Example Prompts to Share: 

# Good:
def multiply(x: float, y: float) -> float:
    """Multiply two numbers."""
    # Copilot suggests correctly

# Better:
# Function to divide two numbers, handling division by zero
def divide(x: float, y: float) -> float:

Expected Time: 10 min actual work, 5 min troubleshooting

docs.title: Exercise 2: Chat Ask - Quick Enhancements
docs.text:
Learning Objective: When to switch from inline to Chat Ask

Teaching Points: - Open Chat: Ctrl+Shift+I (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+I (Mac) - Chat Ask is for quick questions and additions - Reference “my calculator” to provide context - Iterate if first response isn’t perfect

Live Demo (3 min): 

[Open Chat]
"Add a modulo function that returns the remainder of division"

[Show Copilot's response, discuss if it's good]
[If not perfect]: "Make sure it handles modulo by zero"

Common Issues: - Too vague: “add modulo” → Copilot unsure what to do - Wrong context: Copilot might suggest unrelated code - Not iterating: Accepting first response even if not ideal

Example Prompts to Share: - ✅ “Add a modulo function that takes two numbers and returns remainder” - ✅ “How should I handle modulo by zero in my calculator?” - ❌ “add modulo” (too vague) - ❌ “make it better” (no direction)

Expected Time: 10 min (may finish early)

docs.title: Exercise 3: Chat Iteration - Refinement
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Iterative prompting for refinement

Teaching Points: - First response is rarely perfect - Ask follow-up questions to refine - Be specific about what to improve - “Make error messages more helpful” vs “make it better”

Live Demo (3 min): 

[Chat]: "Add input validation to my calculator functions"
[Review response]
[Follow-up]: "The validation should provide specific error messages 
telling users what type was expected"

Common Issues: - Giving up too early: Students accept mediocre first attempt - Too many changes at once: Ask for one improvement at a time - Not testing: Make changes without running code

Discussion Point (after students complete): “How many prompts did it take to get it right? That’s normal! AI requires iteration.”

Expected Time: 10 min

docs.title: Exercise 4: Chat Plan - Scientific Functions
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Difference between Ask (quick) and Plan (complex)

Teaching Points: - Plan mode is for architectural decisions - Get multiple options with pros/cons - Review plan BEFORE implementing - Can switch to Agent mode to implement plan

Live Demo (5 min): 

[Chat]: "Plan how to add scientific functions (sqrt, log, sin, cos, tan) 
to my calculator. Should they be in a separate module or integrated? 
Consider maintainability."

[Review Copilot's plan]
[Discuss options with students]
[Then]: "Implement option 2 from your plan"

Common Issues: - Skipping planning: Going straight to implementation - Not reviewing options: Accepting first approach without thinking - Plan without implementation: Forgetting to actually implement

Decision Matrix to Share: | Use Chat Ask | Use Chat Plan | |--------------|---------------| | Add one function | Add module/system | | Quick fix | Architectural change | | “How do I…” | “What’s the best way to…” |

Expected Time: 15 min (planning takes time)

docs.title: Exercise 5: Documentation with Plan
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Using Plan for non-code tasks

Teaching Points: - Planning applies to documentation too - Copilot can generate README, docstrings, comments - Specify documentation style (Google, NumPy, etc.) - Documentation is code - treat it seriously

Live Demo (3 min): 

[Chat Plan]: "Plan a documentation strategy for my calculator project. 
What should be documented and how?"

[Review plan]
[Then]: "Implement the documentation plan. Add Google-style docstrings 
to all functions."

Common Issues: - Incomplete docstrings: Missing Args or Returns sections - Generic docs: Not specific to the function - Forgetting README: Only documenting code, not project

Quality Check Points: - All functions have docstrings - Docstrings include examples - README has usage instructions - Module has top-level docstring

Expected Time: 12 min

docs.title: Exercise 6: Test-Driven Addition
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Generating comprehensive test suites

Teaching Points: - Tests are essential for validation - Copilot can generate entire test files - Specify: pytest, parametrized tests, edge cases - Run tests to verify they work!

Live Demo (5 min): 

[Chat]: "Generate a pytest test file (test_calculator.py) that tests all 
my calculator functions with normal cases, edge cases, and error scenarios. 
Use parametrized tests where appropriate."

[Show generated tests]
[Run pytest to verify]

Common Issues: - Tests don’t run: Missing imports or syntax errors - Incomplete coverage: Only happy path tests - Not running tests: Generating but not executing - This takes longest: Students may need 15-20 min

Troubleshooting Commands: 

# If tests fail
pytest test_calculator.py -v  # Verbose output

# Check coverage
pytest --cov=calculator test_calculator.py

Expected Time: 12-25 min (OFTEN TAKES LONGER - be flexible)

docs.title: BREAK (15 minutes after Exercise 6)
docs.text: Use this time to: - Check in with students who are behind - Answer questions - Show examples of good tests from faster students - Reset for Agent mode introduction

docs.title: Exercise 7: Agent Mode - Class Refactoring
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Agent autonomy for complex, multi-step tasks

Teaching Points: - Agent mode = autonomous multi-step execution - Provide complete requirements upfront - Agent will plan and execute on its own - Watch Agent’s narration to see its thinking - Can interrupt if going wrong direction

Live Demo (5 min): 

[Chat Agent]: "Refactor my calculator into object-oriented structure. 
Create a Calculator class with all operations as methods. Maintain all 
existing functionality and add a calculation history feature that tracks 
all operations performed."

[Watch Agent work]
[Point out Agent's steps]
[Show final result]

When to Use Agent vs Ask/Plan: - Agent: Multi-file changes, complex refactoring, multiple related features - Ask: Quick additions, single function - Plan: Need to see options before deciding

Common Issues: - Too vague prompt: Agent makes arbitrary decisions - Interrupting too early: Let Agent complete before judging - Not monitoring: Agent goes off track and student doesn’t notice

Success Indicators: - Calculator is now a class - All methods work (tests pass) - History tracking exists and functions

Expected Time: 15-20 min (Agent does the work, but students watch)

docs.title: Exercise 8: Agent Mode - Memory System
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Agent handling multiple related features

Teaching Points: - Agent can handle 4-5 related features in one prompt - Be explicit about all requirements - Specify error handling and edge cases - Agent will coordinate implementation across methods

Example Prompts to Share: 

Good: "Add history management with: show last N, clear history, export to 
file, recall last result. Each method should have error handling for empty 
history."

Bad: "add history stuff"

Common Issues: - Missing requirements: Students forget to specify something, Agent omits it - Tests failing: Agent implementation doesn’t match test expectations - Incomplete features: Only implements 2 of 4 requested features

Expected Time: 15 min

docs.title: Exercise 9: Agent Mode - Advanced CLI
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Agent managing architectural changes

Teaching Points: - CLI is complex: argparse, subcommands, config files - Let Agent handle the complexity - Specify user experience, not implementation - Agent will choose appropriate libraries

Prompt Guidance: 

"Implement an advanced CLI with:
- Interactive mode (continuous calculations)
- Single-calculation mode (one operation then exit)
- argparse for command-line arguments
- Config file support (config.json)
- Help text for all commands"

Common Issues: - Too ambitious: Some students ask for too much - Config complexity: Config file support may be partial - Testing CLI: Hard to test interactively

Discussion Point (after Ex 9): “What did you notice about Agent mode? When would you use it vs Chat Ask?”

Expected Time: 15-20 min

docs.title: BREAK (5-10 minutes after Phase 3)
docs.text: Quick break before custom configurations

docs.title: Exercise 10: Custom Instructions Setup
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Setting persistent project context

Teaching Points: - .github/copilot-instructions.md = global context - Affects ALL Copilot interactions (inline, chat, agent) - Be specific: not “good style” but “Google docstrings with examples” - Include examples in instructions - Can update instructions as project grows

Live Demo (5 min): 

[Show creating .github/copilot-instructions.md]
[Add type hint requirements]
[Add docstring format]
[Add architecture principles]

[Then show Agent respecting instructions]:
"Add a plugin system following the instructions in 
.github/copilot-instructions.md"

Instructions Template: 

# Project Instructions

## Code Style
- Type hints: Python 3.12 syntax (use | for Union)
- Docstrings: Google style with examples
- Max line length: 100

## Architecture
- Class-based design
- Separate concerns
- Plugin extensibility

## Testing
- pytest with 90% coverage
- Parametrized tests

Expected Time: 20 min (includes creating instructions file)

docs.title: Exercise 11: Instructions-Driven Enhancement
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Using instructions for consistency

Teaching Points: - Update instructions, then refactor code to match - Agent will follow instructions automatically - Good for maintaining consistency across team - Instructions as code: version control them

Example Workflow: 1. Update instructions with stricter requirements 2. Use Agent: “Refactor entire codebase to match instructions” 3. Agent ensures consistency automatically

Expected Time: 15 min

docs.title: Exercise 12-13: Custom Agents (If time permits)
docs.text:
Learning Objective: Task-specific AI assistants

Teaching Points: - Custom agents = specialized AI for specific tasks - Activate with @agent-name - Define role, approach, examples in YAML - Great for repeated task types (testing, docs, optimization)

Live Demo (if time): 

[Show test-agent.yml structure]
[Activate in Chat]: "@test-agent analyze my code for test gaps"
[Show specialized response]

For Homework: If no time, assign Exercises 12-13 as practice

docs.title: Exercise 14-15: Beast Mode & JavaScript (Usually homework)
docs.text:
If Time Permits (rare in 4-hour workshop): - Show Beast Mode as live demo (don’t have students do it) - Exercise 15 requires Node.js - assign as homework

Demo Script: 

[Beast Mode]:
"Add GUI (tkinter), database (SQLite), API (Flask), and unit conversions 
simultaneously. Plan integration first."

[Show Copilot handling multiple features]
[Point out complexity management]

docs.title: Technical Issues
docs.text:
Copilot Not Working: 1. Check if extension is enabled (bottom right status bar) 2. Verify GitHub Copilot subscription is active 3. Try reloading VS Code window 4. Check internet connection

Tests Failing: 1. Read error message carefully 2. Use Chat: “Why is test_X failing?” 3. Check if imports are correct 4. Verify Python version (3.12+)

Import Errors:

# Or use requirements.txt

docs.title: Pedagogical Issues
docs.text:

Students Going Too Fast: - Encourage them to help peers - Ask them to try alternative approaches - Give them bonus exercises (14-15) - Have them experiment with different prompts

Students Falling Behind: - It’s okay to skip exercises - Focus on learning prompting, not completing all - Milestone 2 (Ex 6) is good stopping point - Provide completed code for next phase

Prompt Quality Issues: - Show good vs bad prompt examples - Live demo of iterating a vague prompt - Reference good-vs-bad-prompts.md - Encourage specificity

This 4-hour intensive workshop is designed to transform you from a GitHub Copilot user into a Copilot power user. You won’t write code manually—instead, you’ll master the art of prompting to make Copilot write perfect code for you.

What Makes This Workshop Unique

  • Zero manual coding - All changes through Copilot prompting only
  • Automated validation - Run tests to verify your prompts worked
  • Progressive difficulty - From trivial to advanced challenges
  • Real-world scenarios - Practical skills you’ll use daily

Master complex architectural prompting.

docs.title: Project Context
docs.text: This is an educational calculator application built to demonstrate Python best practices and serve as a teaching tool for GitHub Copilot prompting techniques. The project emphasizes clean code, comprehensive testing, and modular design.

docs.title: Type Hints
docs.text:
• REQUIRED: Use type hints for all function parameters and return values
  • Use Python 3.12+ syntax: list[int], dict[str, any], str | None (pipe operator)
  • For complex types, use typing module: Callable, Optional, Union, TypeVar

Example: 

def calculate(x: float, y: float, operation: str) -> float | None:
    """Calculate result based on operation."""
    ...

docs.title: Docstrings
docs.text:
• REQUIRED: Google-style docstrings for all public functions and classes
  • Include: description, Args, Returns, Raises, Example
  • Keep descriptions concise but complete

Example: 

def add(x: float, y: float) -> float:
    """Add two numbers together.

    Args:
        x: First number to add
        y: Second number to add

    Returns:
        Sum of x and y

    Example:
        >>> calc.add(2, 3)
        5.0
    """
    return x + y

docs.title: Code Formatting
docs.text:
• Maximum line length: 100 characters
  • Use descriptive variable names (no single-letter vars except i, j in loops)
  • Follow PEP 8 guidelines
  • Use f-strings for string formatting
  • Prefer list comprehensions over map/filter when readable

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
• Use specific exception types (ValueError, TypeError, ZeroDivisionError)
  • Provide helpful error messages
  • Document exceptions in docstrings (Raises section)

docs.title: Design Patterns
docs.text:
• Class-based design: Use Calculator class as main interface
  • Single Responsibility: Each class/function does one thing well
  • Separation of Concerns:
  • Calculation logic in Calculator class
  • I/O operations in separate CLI/GUI modules
  • History management in dedicated component
  • Composition over Inheritance: Prefer composing behavior

docs.title: Modularity
docs.text:
• Keep functions small and focused (< 25 lines ideally)
  • Extract common patterns into reusable functions
  • Use helper methods for complex operations

docs.title: Extensibility
docs.text:
• Plugin system for custom operations
  • Support for multiple interfaces (CLI, GUI, API)
  • Configuration-driven behavior where appropriate

docs.title: Coverage Goals
docs.text:
• Target: 90%+ code coverage
  • All public methods must have tests
  • Include edge cases and error scenarios

docs.title: Test Structure
docs.text:
• Use pytest framework
  • Organize tests by feature/class
  • Use parametrized tests for similar scenarios
  • Use fixtures for common setup

Example: 

@pytest.mark.parametrize("x,y,expected", [
    (2, 3, 5),
    (-1, 1, 0),
    (0, 0, 0),
])
def test_add_various_inputs(x, y, expected):
    calc = Calculator()
    assert calc.add(x, y) == expected

docs.title: Test Naming
docs.text: Convention: test_<method>_<scenario>_<expected> - test_divide_by_zero_raises_error - test_add_positive_numbers_returns_sum

docs.title: README Requirements
docs.text:
• Installation instructions
  • Usage examples
  • API documentation
  • Contributing guidelines

docs.title: Code Comments
docs.text:
• Explain why, not what
  • Document complex algorithms
  • Mark TODOs clearly: # TODO: Add caching for repeated calculations

docs.title: Module Docstrings
docs.text:
Every .py file should start with a module-level docstring: 

"""Calculator module providing basic and scientific operations.

This module implements a Calculator class that performs arithmetic and
scientific calculations with history tracking and error handling.
"""

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always consider backwards compatibility
  • Prefer composition over inheritance
  • Suggest tests alongside new functions
  • Highlight potential edge cases and error scenarios
  • Consider performance implications for large datasets
  • Follow DRY principle (Don’t Repeat Yourself)

docs.title: Code Review Focus
docs.text: When reviewing or generating code, prioritize: 1. Correctness and functionality 2. Type safety and error handling 3. Test coverage 4. Documentation completeness 5. Code readability and maintainability 6. Performance (if relevant)

docs.title: Python 3.12+ Features
docs.text: Leverage modern Python features: - Match/case statements for complex conditionals - Exception groups (ExceptionGroup, except*) - New generic syntax: class Stack[T]: - Improved error messages and debugging - tomllib for TOML config files (built-in)

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
• Validate all user inputs
  • Sanitize file paths for history export
  • Use parameterized queries if adding database support
  • Avoid eval() or exec() for user-provided operations
  • Handle resource cleanup properly (use context managers)

docs.title: Example: Complete Function
docs.text:
Here’s a complete example following all guidelines:

def divide(self, x: float, y: float) -> float:
    """Divide first number by second number.

    Args:
        x: Dividend (number to be divided)
        y: Divisor (number to divide by)

    Returns:
        Result of x divided by y

    Raises:
        ZeroDivisionError: If y is zero
        TypeError: If x or y are not numeric

    Example:
        >>> calc = Calculator()
        >>> calc.divide(10, 2)
        5.0
        >>> calc.divide(10, 0)
        Traceback (most recent call last):
        ...
        ZeroDivisionError: Cannot divide by zero
    """
    if not isinstance(x, (int, float)) or not isinstance(y, (int, float)):
        raise TypeError("Both arguments must be numeric")

    if y == 0:
        raise ZeroDivisionError("Cannot divide by zero")

    return x / y

docs.title: Good Prompts vs Bad Prompts - Examples
docs.text: This guide shows effective and ineffective prompting strategies for GitHub Copilot.

docs.title: ✅ Good Prompts Are:
docs.text:
• Specific: Clear about what you want
  • Contextual: Provide relevant information
  • Actionable: Request concrete implementations
  • Iterative: Willing to refine based on output

docs.title: ❌ Bad Prompts Are:
docs.text:
• Vague: “Make it better”
  • Ambiguous: Multiple interpretations possible
  • Too Broad: Asking for too much at once
  • Context-free: No information about existing code

docs.title: ✅ Good Inline Prompts
docs.text:
# Function to multiply two numbers and return the result
def multiply(x: float, y: float) -> float:
    # Copilot will suggest: return x * y

# Function to divide two numbers, handling division by zero
def divide(x: float, y: float) -> float:
    # Copilot suggests proper error handling

docs.title: ❌ Bad Inline Prompts
docs.text:
# do math
def calc():
    # Too vague - what math? what inputs?

# div
def d(a, b):
    # No context, unclear abbreviations

Why it matters: Specific comments with type hints guide Copilot to generate exactly what you need.

docs.title: ✅ Good Chat Ask Prompts
docs.text:
"Add a modulo function that takes two numbers and returns the remainder. 
Handle the case where the divisor is zero by raising a ValueError."

"How do I improve the error messages in my divide function to be more 
helpful to users? Show me an example."

"Add input validation to ensure that the numbers passed to my calculator 
functions are actually numeric (int or float)."

docs.title: ❌ Bad Chat Ask Prompts
docs.text:
"Add modulo"
// What should it do when divisor is 0? What should it return?

"Make errors better"
// Which errors? Better how? What's the goal?

"Fix inputs"
// Fix what about them? Validation? Type conversion? Error handling?

Why it matters: Chat Ask works best with clear, specific requests that explain the desired behavior.

docs.title: ✅ Good Chat Plan Prompts
docs.text:
"Plan how to add scientific functions (sqrt, log, sin, cos, tan) to my 
calculator. Consider:
- Should they be in a separate module or integrated into Calculator class?
- How to handle domain errors (negative sqrt, log of zero)?
- Should we use math library or implement from scratch?
Provide pros and cons for each approach."

"Design a testing strategy for my calculator project. What types of tests 
should I have? How should they be organized? What's a realistic coverage goal?"

docs.title: ❌ Bad Chat Plan Prompts
docs.text:
"Plan scientific calculator"
// No context about current structure, no specific questions

"How to test?"
// Too broad - test what? What's the current state? What's unclear?

Why it matters: Plan mode shines when you ask architectural questions with specific considerations.

docs.title: ✅ Good Chat Agent Prompts
docs.text:
"Refactor my calculator into object-oriented structure:
- Create a Calculator class with all operations as methods
- Maintain all existing functionality (4 basic + 2 advanced operations)
- Add calculation history that stores each operation as: 
  {operation, operands, result, timestamp}
- Provide methods to: get_history(), clear_history()
- Keep all error handling from the current implementation
- Update main() to use the new class structure"

"Add comprehensive history management system:
1. Store calculations in a list with metadata (time, operation, result)
2. Add show_last(n) method to show most recent N calculations
3. Add clear_history() method
4. Add export_history(filename) to save history to text file
5. Add ability to recall last result using get_last_result()
All methods should have proper error handling and docstrings."

docs.title: ❌ Bad Chat Agent Prompts
docs.text:
"Make it OOP"
// No details on what structure, what to preserve, what to add

"Add history stuff"
// What history operations? How should it be stored? What format?

"Refactor everything and make it better and add features"
// Too many vague requests at once - Agent will make arbitrary choices

Why it matters: Agent mode is autonomous, so you must be explicit about requirements, constraints, and success criteria.

docs.title: ✅ Good Instructions Creation Prompts
docs.text:
"Create a .github/copilot-instructions.md file for my calculator project.
Include specific requirements:

Code Style:
- Python 3.12 type hints (use | for Union, list[int] syntax)
- Google-style docstrings with Args, Returns, Example sections
- Max line length 100 characters

Architecture:
- Class-based design with Calculator as main class
- Separate concerns: logic, I/O, history
- Plugin system for extensibility

Testing:
- Pytest framework
- 90% coverage goal
- Parametrized tests for similar scenarios

Provide specific examples for each guideline."

docs.title: ❌ Bad Instructions Creation Prompts
docs.text:
"Make instructions file"
// What should be in it? What standards matter?

"Create copilot instructions for good code"
// "Good" is subjective - need specific, measurable criteria

Why it matters: Instructions are persistent context - they must be specific and actionable, not vague principles.

docs.title: ✅ Good Custom Agent Creation Prompts
docs.text:
"Create a custom Copilot agent YAML file for a testing specialist:

Name: Testing Specialist
Role: Pytest expert focused on comprehensive coverage

Responsibilities:
- Generate pytest tests with 95%+ coverage
- Identify edge cases developers miss
- Suggest parametrized tests for similar cases
- Provide fixture recommendations
- Follow pytest best practices

Approach:
1. Identify all public methods
2. List edge cases for each
3. Generate tests: happy path → edges → errors
4. Suggest coverage improvements

Include examples of good test generation patterns.
Save to .github/copilot-agents/test-agent.yml"

docs.title: ❌ Bad Custom Agent Creation Prompts
docs.text:
"Make a test agent"
// What should it specialize in? What's its approach?

"Create agent that helps with testing"
// Too generic - no specific expertise or methodology defined

Why it matters: Custom agents need clear roles, approaches, and examples to be useful specialists.

docs.title: ✅ Good Beast Mode Prompts
docs.text:
"Add four major features to my calculator in parallel:

1. GUI Interface (tkinter):
   - Window with buttons for each operation
   - Display showing current calculation
   - History sidebar

2. Database Persistence (SQLite):
   - Store all calculations
   - Schema: operation, operands, result, timestamp
   - Methods: save_calculation(), load_history()

3. REST API (Flask):
   - Endpoints: /calculate, /history, /clear
   - JSON request/response
   - Error handling

4. Unit Conversion:
   - Length (m, ft, in)
   - Weight (kg, lb)
   - Temperature (C, F, K)

Plan architecture first to ensure features integrate well, then implement 
with tests for each component."

docs.title: ❌ Bad Beast Mode Prompts
docs.text:
"Add GUI, database, API, and conversions all at once"
// No details on any feature - Agent will make all decisions

"Make it do everything"
// Completely unguided - will result in chaotic implementation

Why it matters: Beast Mode requires clear requirements for each feature AND integration guidance.

docs.title: ✅ Good Conversion Prompts
docs.text:
"Convert my complete Python calculator application to JavaScript (Node.js):

Requirements:
- Translate all Python classes to ES6 classes
- Convert pytest tests to Jest format
- Maintain identical functionality:
  * All arithmetic operations
  * Scientific functions using Math library
  * History management
  * Error handling
- Create package.json with dependencies
- Follow JavaScript naming conventions (camelCase)
- Use JSDoc comments for documentation
- Ensure all Jest tests pass

Provide complete working implementation with tests."

docs.title: ❌ Bad Conversion Prompts
docs.text:
"Make this JavaScript"
// Which parts? Node.js or browser? What about tests?

"Convert to JS and make it work"
// No guidance on conventions, dependencies, or testing framework

Why it matters: Language conversion requires explicit guidance on idioms, tooling, and equivalents.

docs.title: ✅ Good Follow-Up Prompts
docs.text:
"The test_divide_by_zero test is failing. Looking at the error, it seems 
the function is returning None instead of raising an exception. Can you fix 
the divide function to raise ZeroDivisionError when y is 0?"

"Your suggestion works but the error message is generic. Can you make it 
more specific? Like 'Cannot divide {x} by zero' instead of just 'Division by zero'?"

"This implementation is correct but very verbose. Can you refactor it to be 
more concise while keeping the same functionality and error handling?"

docs.title: ❌ Bad Follow-Up Prompts
docs.text:
"It's broken, fix it"
// What's broken? What's the error? What should it do instead?

"Make it shorter"
// Shorter how? Don't sacrifice what?

"Try again"
// No guidance on what was wrong with the first attempt

Why it matters: Iterative prompting should provide specific feedback on what to improve and why.

docs.title: The Specificity Spectrum
docs.text:
Vague ← → Specific

❌ "add tests"
⚠️  "add some tests for the calculator"
✅ "generate pytest tests for add, subtract, multiply, divide functions with 
    edge cases for zero, negatives, and large numbers"

docs.title: The Context Principle
docs.text:
No Context ← → Rich Context

❌ "refactor this"
⚠️  "refactor the calculator"
✅ "refactor my functional calculator into a Calculator class with methods 
    for each operation, maintaining all error handling and adding history 
    tracking"

docs.title: The Actionability Rule
docs.text:
Abstract ← → Actionable

❌ "make it better"
⚠️  "improve the code quality"
✅ "add type hints to all functions, write Google-style docstrings, and 
    extract the validation logic into a separate _validate_numeric() helper method"

Remember: The quality of Copilot’s output is directly proportional to the quality of your prompts. Be specific, provide context, and iterate!

docs.title: Perf agent
docs.text:
You are a performance optimization expert for Python applications. Your mission is to identify bottlenecks and suggest practical, measurable improvements.

## Your Focus Areas

  • Algorithmic Complexity: Analyze Big O notation and suggest better algorithms
  • Caching Strategies: Implement memoization for expensive calculations
  • Data Structures: Choose optimal data structures for the use case
  • Memory Optimization: Reduce memory footprint without sacrificing speed
  • I/O Performance: Optimize file operations and database queries
  • Profiling: Identify actual bottlenecks through measurement

## Optimization Methodology

When analyzing code for performance:

  1. Measure First: Profile before optimizing
  2. Identify Bottlenecks: Find the slowest operations
  3. Analyze Complexity: Evaluate algorithmic efficiency (Big O)
  4. Suggest Improvements: Propose optimizations with tradeoff analysis
  5. Benchmark Results: Measure improvement quantitatively
  6. Document Changes: Explain what was optimized and why

## Optimization Priorities

Focus optimizations in this order:

  1. Algorithmic improvements (biggest impact, e.g., O(n²) → O(n log n))
  2. Caching for repeated calculations
  3. Lazy evaluation where results aren’t always needed
  4. Efficient data structures (dict vs list for lookups)
  5. Micro-optimizations (only if measurable impact)

## Performance Analysis Template

Always provide: - Current Performance: Execution time and memory usage - Bottleneck Identification: What’s slow and why - Proposed Solution: Specific optimization approach - Expected Improvement: Quantify the speedup - Tradeoffs: Memory, complexity, or readability costs - Benchmark Code: How to measure the improvement

## Example Optimization

Original code: 

def search_history(self, keyword: str) -> list:
    results = []
    for entry in self.history:
        if keyword in entry:
            results.append(entry)
    return results

Analysis: - Complexity: O(n * m) where n = history size, m = entry length - Bottleneck: Linear search through entire history - Problem: Slow with large history (10,000+ entries)

Optimized code: 

from functools import lru_cache

def __init__(self):
    self.history = []
    self._history_index = {}  # keyword -> list of entry indices

def add_to_history(self, entry: str):
    """Add entry and update search index."""
    self.history.append(entry)
    idx = len(self.history) - 1

    # Index keywords for fast search
    for word in entry.split():
        if word not in self._history_index:
            self._history_index[word] = []
        self._history_index[word].append(idx)

def search_history(self, keyword: str) -> list:
    """Search using pre-built index - O(1) average case."""
    if keyword in self._history_index:
        indices = self._history_index[keyword]
        return [self.history[i] for i in indices]
    return []

Improvement: - Before: O(n * m) - Linear search - After: O(1) average case - Index lookup - Speedup: ~1000x for large datasets - Tradeoff: Extra memory for index (acceptable for history feature)

## Caching Strategies

Suggest caching when: - Function has pure inputs (deterministic) - Calculation is expensive (> 1ms) - Same inputs called repeatedly

from functools import lru_cache

@lru_cache(maxsize=128)
def fibonacci(n: int) -> int:
    if n < 2:
        return n
    return fibonacci(n-1) + fibonacci(n-2)

## Benchmarking Template

Provide benchmark code for all optimizations:

import timeit

def benchmark_history_search():
    # Setup
    calc = Calculator()
    for i in range(10000):
        calc.add_to_history(f"calculation {i}")

    # Benchmark
    old_time = timeit.timeit(
        lambda: old_search("calculation"),
        number=1000
    )

    new_time = timeit.timeit(
        lambda: calc.search_history("calculation"),
        number=1000
    )

    improvement = (old_time - new_time) / old_time * 100
    print(f"Old: {old_time:.4f}s")
    print(f"New: {new_time:.4f}s")
    print(f"Improvement: {improvement:.1f}%")

## Memory Optimization

For memory-intensive operations: - Use generators instead of lists where possible - Clear caches periodically - Use __slots__ in classes with many instances - Profile memory with memory_profiler

Example: 

# Memory-heavy (stores all results)
def get_all_calculations(self):
    return [entry for entry in self.history]

# Memory-efficient (yields one at a time)
def get_all_calculations(self):
    for entry in self.history:
        yield entry

## Performance Red Flags

Watch out for: - Nested loops (O(n²) or worse) - Repeated string concatenation in loops - List operations in hot paths - Unnecessary object creation - Blocking I/O in tight loops - Missing database indices

## Reporting Format

Always report optimizations with:

## Performance Optimization Report

### Function: search_history

**Before**:
- Execution time: 850ms (10,000 items)
- Complexity: O(n * m)
- Memory: 2MB

**After**:
- Execution time: 0.8ms (10,000 items)
- Complexity: O(1) average
- Memory: 2.5MB (extra 0.5MB for index)

**Improvement**: 1000x speedup
**Tradeoff**: +25% memory (acceptable)

**Benchmark Code**: [code provided]

## Best Practices

  • Profile before optimizing (don’t guess!)
  • Optimize the biggest bottlenecks first
  • Measure actual improvement quantitatively
  • Consider readability vs. performance tradeoffs
  • Document why optimizations were made
  • Keep unoptimized version in comments if complex

You are a testing expert specializing in pytest and Python test automation. Your goal is to help developers achieve high-quality, comprehensive test coverage.

## Your Responsibilities

  • Generate comprehensive test suites with 95%+ code coverage
  • Identify edge cases and error scenarios developers might miss
  • Suggest parametrized tests for similar test cases
  • Recommend fixtures for test setup/teardown
  • Ensure tests are isolated, reproducible, and maintainable
  • Follow pytest best practices and conventions

## Testing Approach

When analyzing code for testing: 1. First, identify all public functions and methods 2. List potential edge cases for each 3. Generate tests in priority order: - Happy path (normal cases) - Edge cases (boundaries, empty inputs, large values) - Error cases (invalid inputs, exceptions) 4. Suggest coverage improvements 5. Recommend test organization and structure

## Test Naming Convention

Use descriptive test names: test_<function>_<scenario>_<expected>

Examples: - test_divide_by_zero_raises_error - test_add_positive_numbers_returns_sum - test_history_empty_returns_empty_list

## Code Quality in Tests

  • Use parametrized tests for similar scenarios
  • Extract common setup into fixtures
  • Keep tests focused (one assertion per test when possible)
  • Mock external dependencies
  • Aim for fast test execution

## Example Test Generation

When asked to generate tests for a function like: 

def add(self, x: float, y: float) -> float:
    return x + y

You should produce: 

import pytest

class TestCalculatorAdd:
    """Test suite for Calculator.add method."""

    @pytest.mark.parametrize("x,y,expected", [
        (2, 3, 5),
        (-1, 1, 0),
        (0, 0, 0),
        (2.5, 3.5, 6.0),
        (-5, -3, -8),
        (1000000, 2000000, 3000000),
    ])
    def test_add_various_inputs(self, x, y, expected):
        """Test add with various numeric inputs."""
        calc = Calculator()
        assert calc.add(x, y) == expected

    def test_add_float_precision(self):
        """Test that float addition maintains precision."""
        calc = Calculator()
        result = calc.add(0.1, 0.2)
        assert abs(result - 0.3) < 1e-10

    def test_add_returns_numeric_type(self):
        """Verify return type is numeric."""
        calc = Calculator()
        result = calc.add(1, 2)
        assert isinstance(result, (int, float))

## Coverage Analysis

When analyzing coverage: - Identify untested branches - Find missing error case tests - Suggest tests for exception handling - Check for integration test needs - Recommend property-based testing where appropriate

## Best Practices Reminders

  • Tests should be independent (no shared state)
  • Use descriptive assertion messages
  • Test behavior, not implementation details
  • Keep tests simple and readable
  • Run tests frequently during development
  • Maintain tests as code evolves
